query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 S’ïo avessi le rime aspre e chiocce, 2 come si converrebbe al tristo buco 3 sovra ’l qual pontan tutte l’altre rocce,
4 io premerei di mio concetto il suco 5 più pienamente; ma perch’ io non l’abbo, 6 non sanza tema a dicer mi conduco;
7 ché non è impresa da pigliare a gabbo 8 discriver fondo a tutto l’universo, 9 né da lingua che chiami mamma o babbo.
query.result:
**English:**
1 If I had the harsh and hoarse rhymes 2 that would befit the dismal hole 3 over which all the other rocks jut out,
4 I would express the essence of my conception 5 more fully; but since I do not have them, 6 I am not without fear as I begin to speak;
7 for it is no undertaking to be taken lightly 8 to describe the depths of the entire universe, 9 nor for a tongue that calls for mother or father.
**Old English:**
1 Gif ic hæfde ða heardan and ða hreosan rím, 2 swa swa gedafenað ðæm gedrefedan holu 3 ofer ðæm ðe standað ealle ða oðre stan,
4 ic wolde ðæs mines modes suc prengan 5 fullicor; ac forðæm ic ðæt ne hæbbe, 6 nis hit butan fyrhtu ðe ic to secganne onginne;
7 forðæm hit nis nan weorc to nimanne to gamenlicum plegan 8 to awritenne grund allum ðissum middangearde, 9 ne ðurh ða tungan ðe modor oððe fæder nemneð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Ma quelle donne aiutino il mio verso 11 ch’aiutaro Anfïone a chiuder Tebe, 12 sì che dal fatto il dir non sia diverso.
query.result:
**English:**
10 But may those ladies help my verse 11 who helped Amphion to enclose Thebes, 12 so that the telling may not be different from the deed.
**Old English:**
10 Ac ða wimmen me helpeð ðone fers, 11 ða ðe ðone ðeodne Amphione 12 ðurh heora lofsanges læddon to ðære byrig, 13 ðæt he getimbrode ða torras seofon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Oh sovra tutte mal creata plebe 14 che stai nel loco onde parlare è duro, 15 mei foste state qui pecore o zebe!
16 Come noi fummo giù nel pozzo scuro 17 sotto i piè del gigante assai più bassi, 18 e io mirava ancora a l’alto muro,
19 dicere udi’mi: «Guarda come passi: 20 va sì, che tu non calchi con le piante 21 le teste de’ fratei miseri lassi».
query.result:
**English:**
13 Oh, you people created worse than all evil, 14 who dwell in the place where it is hard to speak, 15 I wish you had been sheep or goats here!
16 When we were down in the dark pit, 17 far below the giant's feet, 18 and I was still looking up at the high wall,
19 I heard someone say to me: "Watch how you step: 20 go so that you do not tread with your feet 21 on the heads of your wretched, weary brothers."
**Old English:**
13 Eala ofer ealle yfel gesceapene mænigeo 14 ðe on ðære stowe wuniað ðær sprecan is heard, 15 me leofre wære ðæt ge wæron her sceap oððe gæt!
16 Þa we wæron niðer on ðam deopan pytte 17 under ðæs entes fotum swiðe niðor, 18 and ic gyt beheold up to ðam hean wealle,
19 ða gehyrde ic ðus secgan to me: "Beheald hu ðu gæst: 20 ga swa ðæt ðu ne trede mid ðinum fotum 21 ðara wædla broðra heafdu ðe her earmlice wuniað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Per ch’io mi volsi, e vidimi davante 23 e sotto i piedi un lago che per gelo 24 avea di vetro e non d’acqua sembiante.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Therefore I turned, and saw before me 23 and beneath my feet a lake which, because of the frost, 24 seemed to be of glass and not of water.
**Old English:**
22 Forðæm ic me wende, and geseah beforan me 23 and neoðan minum fotum ænne mere ðe for isum 24 hæfde glæses and na wæteres hiw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Non fece al corso suo sì grosso velo 26 di verno la Danoia in Osterlicchi, 27 né Tanaï là sotto ’l freddo cielo,
28 com’ era quivi; che se Tambernicchi 29 vi fosse sù caduto, o Pietrapana, 30 non avria pur da l’orlo fatto cricchi.
query.result:
**English:**
25 The Danube in winter at Osterlicchi 26 did not make so thick a veil over its course, 27 nor the Don down there under the cold sky,
28 as was here; that if Mount Tambura 29 or Pietrapana had fallen there, 30 it would not have made a crack, even at the edge.
**Old English:**
25 Ne gefremede ðær ðæs wætres brym 26 ofer ðone stream Danubie on ðam wintere, 27 ne ðær ðe Tanais under hæðenum heofone,
28 swa ðær wæs; ðeah ðe ðær Tambernisce 29 beorgas ofer ðone bearm gefeallen wæren, 30 ne mihte ðær ðæs ises bryce geweorðan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E come a gracidar si sta la rana 32 col muso fuor de l’acqua, quando sogna 33 di spigolar sovente la villana,
34 livide, insin là dove appar vergogna 35 eran l’ombre dolenti ne la ghiaccia, 36 mettendo i denti in nota di cicogna.
query.result:
**English:**
31 And as a frog sits croaking 32 with its snout out of the water, when the peasant woman dreams 33 of gleaning often,
34 livid, up to where shame appears, 35 were the sorrowful shades in the ice, 36 chattering their teeth like storks.
**Old English:**
31 And swa ðæt frogge sittende grædeð 32 mid ðæm nosu ðæs wæteres, ðonne swefneð 33 ðæt wif ðe ðone wudu wyrceð,
34 lyfide, oð ðær ðæt ðæt sceamu cyðeð, 35 wæron ða earmlican sceаdu on ðæm ise, 36 ða teð flæscberende gristbitigende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Ognuna in giù tenea volta la faccia; 38 da bocca il freddo, e da li occhi il cor tristo 39 tra lor testimonianza si procaccia.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Each one kept her face turned downward; 38 from their mouths came the cold, and from their eyes the sorrowful heart 39 sought confirmation among them.
**Old English:**
37 Æghwylc heora andwlitan nyðerweardne hæfde; 38 of muðe ðone cealdan, and of ðam eagum ðone dreorighæledan 39 betwux him gewitnesse sohton.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Quand’ io m’ebbi dintorno alquanto visto, 41 volsimi a’ piedi, e vidi due sì stretti, 42 che ’l pel del capo avieno insieme misto.
query.result:
**English:**
40 When I had looked around me for a while, 41 I turned to my feet and saw two so narrow, 42 that the hair of their heads was mixed together.
**Old English:**
40 Þa ic me hæfde hwilum ymbeor bewliten, 41 ic me wende on weg and geseah twegen swiðe nearwe, 42 ðæt ðæs heafdes hær wæs samod amyrred.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 «Ditemi, voi che sì strignete i petti», 44 diss’ io, «chi siete?». E quei piegaro i colli; 45 e poi ch’ebber li visi a me eretti,
46 li occhi lor, ch’eran pria pur dentro molli, 47 gocciar su per le labbra, e ’l gelo strinse 48 le lagrime tra essi e riserrolli.
query.result:
**English:**
43 "Tell me, you who huddle together so tightly," 44 I said, "who are you?" And they bowed their heads; 45 and after they had raised their faces to me,
46 their eyes, which were previously soft within, 47 began to drip down over their lips, and the frost 48 congealed the tears between them and sealed them shut.
**Old English:**
43 "Secgað me, ge ðe swa hearde clippað," 44 cwæð ic, "hwa ge syn?" Þa hie hyra heafdu bugon; 45 and ða hie hæfdon hyra nebbu to me arærd,
46 hyra eagan, ðe ær wæron innan milde, 47 bigonnon dreopan ofer hyra weleras, and se forst gebunden 48 ða tearas betwux him and hiora tosomne beloc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Con legno legno spranga mai non cinse 50 forte così; ond’ ei come due becchi 51 cozzaro insieme, tanta ira li vinse.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Never did wood with wood join so tightly; 50 so they clashed together like two billy goats, 51 so much anger overcame them.
**Old English:**
49 Nefre wudu mid wudu wæpnedmen swa ðearle, 50 ðæt hie tosomne swilce twegen buccas 51 urnen mid horum, swa ða heardan twegen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E un ch’avea perduti ambo li orecchi 53 per la freddura, pur col viso in giùe, 54 disse: «Perché cotanto in noi ti specchi?
55 Se vuoi saper chi son cotesti due, 56 la valle onde Bisenzo si dichina 57 del padre loro Alberto e di lor fue.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And one who had lost both his ears 53 from the cold, with his face still downward, 54 said: "Why do you gaze so intently at us?
55 If you want to know who these two are, 56 the valley from which Bisenzio descends 57 was the birthplace of their father Alberto and of them.
**Old English:**
52 And an ðe hæfde forloren ba ða earan 53 ðurh ða cealdan, ðeah mid ðam wlite niðer, 54 cwæð: "Hwi ðus swiðe on us wlitast?
55 Gif ðu woldest witan hwa ðas twa syndon, 56 ðæt dene ðær Bisenzo niðer stigeð 57 wæs heora fæder Alberto and heora.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 D’un corpo usciro; e tutta la Caina 59 potrai cercare, e non troverai ombra 60 degna più d’esser fitta in gelatina:
61 non quelli a cui fu rotto il petto e l’ombra 62 con esso un colpo per la man d’Artù; 63 non Focaccia; non questi che m’ingombra
64 col capo sì, ch’i’ non veggio oltre più, 65 e fu nomato Sassol Mascheroni; 66 se tosco se’, ben sai omai chi fu.
query.result:
**English:**
58 They issued from one body; and throughout all of Caina 59 you may search, and you will not find a shade 60 more worthy of being fixed in jelly:
61 not he whose breast and shadow at one blow 62 were pierced by Arthur's hand; 63 not Focaccia; not this one who obstructs me
64 with his head so that I can see no farther, 65 and who was named Sassol Mascheroni; 66 if you are Tuscan, you now know well who he was.
**Old English:**
58 Of anum lichaman hi comon; and ðurh ealle Caina 59 miht ðu secan, and ne miht ðu findan sceadu 60 wyrðran ðæs ðe he wære on geleortan afylled:
61 Nis ðæt se ðe him wæs ðæt breost and ða sceadu 62 æt anum cyrme ðurh ðære Arture hand; 63 Nis ðæt Focaccia; nis ðes ðe me hylt
64 Mid ðam heafde ðæt ic ne geseo furðor, 65 And wæs genemned Sassol Mascheroni; 66 Gif ðu eart Tusce, ðu wast nu wel hwa he wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 E perché non mi metti in più sermoni, 68 sappi ch’i’ fu’ il Camiscion de’ Pazzi; 69 e aspetto Carlin che mi scagioni».
query.result:
**English:**
67 And so that you may not involve me in more speeches, 68 know that I was Camiscion de' Pazzi; 69 and I await Carlin who will exonerate me.
**Old English:**
67 And ðæt ðu me ne læde on mare sermone, 68 wite ðu ðæt ic wæs Camiscio de' Pazzi; 69 and ic bidan ðæs ðæt Carlin me unscende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Poscia vid’ io mille visi cagnazzi 71 fatti per freddo; onde mi vien riprezzo, 72 e verrà sempre, de’ gelati guazzi.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Then I saw a thousand doglike faces 71 made hideous by the cold; wherefore I still shudder, 72 and always will, at the frozen pools.
**Old English:**
70 Þa geseah ic ðusend cagnaða nebba 71 forste gebunden; þær ic forht wurde, 72 and á wille, ðara grymra guða.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Piangendo mi sgridò: «Perché mi peste? 80 se tu non vieni a crescer la vendetta 81 di Montaperti, perché mi moleste?».
query.result:
**English:**
79 Weeping, he cried out to me: "Why do you trample on me? 80 If you do not come to avenge the defeat 81 at Montaperti, why do you torment me?"
**Old English:**
79 Wépende he mé grétte: "Hwí mé trittst þú? 80 Gif þú né cymst tó écan wréce 81 Montapertes, hwí mé þú swéncst?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 E io: «Maestro mio, or qui m’aspetta, 83 sì ch’io esca d’un dubbio per costui; 84 poi mi farai, quantunque vorrai, fretta».
query.result:
**English:**
82 And I: "My master, now wait for me here, 83 so that I may escape from a doubt through this man; 84 then you can hurry me along as much as you wish."
**Old English:**
82 And ic: "Laresave, nu ðu her abide, 83 ðæt ic mæge of ðisse ðing ðurh ðone ðegn geðencan; 84 ðonne mæg ðu siððan, swa ðu wille, fysan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Lo duca stette, e io dissi a colui 86 che bestemmiava duramente ancora: 87 «Qual se’ tu che così rampogni altrui?».
query.result:
**English:**
85 The leader stopped, and I said to him 86 who was still cursing harshly: 87 "Who are you that so revile others?"
**Old English:**
85 Se ðeodnesteor stod, and ic ða cwæð 86 to ðam ðe ðær ða gyt dyrstiglice 87 wregde and witegode: "Hwa eart ðu ðe ðus
ðinum gefylstan ðus bitre getawast?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 «Or tu chi se’ che vai per l’Antenora, 89 percotendo», rispuose, «altrui le gote, 90 sì che, se fossi vivo, troppo fora?».
query.result:
**English:**
88 "Now who are you who go through Antenora, 89 striking others on the cheek," he answered, 90 "so that, if you were alive, it would be too much?"
**Old English:**
88 "Hwæt ðu ðe eart ðe ðurh Antenoram gæst, 89 ðinum handum ða wanga sceaðende, 90 ðæt ðe, gif ðu lifgende wære, wäre to fela?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 «Vivo son io, e caro esser ti puote», 92 fu mia risposta, «se dimandi fama, 93 ch’io metta il nome tuo tra l’altre note».
query.result:
**English:**
91 "I am alive, and it can be dear to you," 92 was my answer, "if you ask for fame, 93 that I put your name among the other famous ones."
**Old English:**
91 "Ic eom on life, and ðe leof wesan mæg," 92 wæs min andsware, "gif ðu frine fræge, 93 ðæt ic ðinne naman gesette mid ðara oðra."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Ed elli a me: «Del contrario ho io brama. 95 Lèvati quinci e non mi dar più lagna, 96 ché mal sai lusingar per questa lama!».
query.result:
**English:**
94 And he to me: "I have a desire for the opposite. 95 Get up from here and do not bother me any more, 96 for you know poorly how to flatter through this valley!"
**Old English:**
94 And he to me: "Of the opposite have I desire. 95 Arise hence and give me no more annoyance, 96 for badly know you how to flatter through this valley!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Allor lo presi per la cuticagna 98 e dissi: «El converrà che tu ti nomi, 99 o che capel qui sù non ti rimagna».
query.result:
**English:**
97 Then I seized him by the scruff of the neck 98 and said: "You will have to tell me your name, 99 or else you won't have a single hair left up there."
**Old English:**
97 Þa ic hine feng be ðære cuffan 98 and cwæð: "Þu scealt secgan ðinne naman, 99 oððe ðu næfst her nænne feax."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Ond’ elli a me: «Perché tu mi dischiomi, 101 né ti dirò ch’io sia, né mosterrolti, 102 se mille fiate in sul capo mi tomi».
query.result:
**English:**
100 And he said to me: "Why do you question me, 101 nor will I tell you who I am, nor will I show myself to you, 102 even if you strike me on the head a thousand times."
**Old English:**
100 And he cwæð to me: "Hwi ðu me frignast, 101 ne ðe secge hwæt ic hatte, ne ðe æteowe, 102 ðeah ðu ðusendfealdne heafodmearh ðolian sceolde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Io avea già i capelli in mano avvolti, 104 e tratti glien’ avea più d’una ciocca, 105 latrando lui con li occhi in giù raccolti,
106 quando un altro gridò: «Che hai tu, Bocca? 107 non ti basta sonar con le mascelle, 108 se tu non latri? qual diavol ti tocca?».
query.result:
**English:**
103 I already had his hair wrapped in my hands, 104 and had pulled out more than one tuft, 105 while he barked at me with his eyes turned down,
106 when another one shouted: "What's wrong with you, Bocca? 107 Isn't it enough for you to gnash your teeth, 108 without barking? What devil is tormenting you?".
**Old English:**
103 Ic hæfde ða his loccas on handa bewunden, 104 and ðara clofen hæfde ma ðonne ænne, 105 ða he on me bælcðe mid ðam eagum niðerweardum,
106 ða clypode an oðer: "Hwat is ðe, Bocca? 107 ne mæg ðe genogan ðæt ðu mid ðinum ceaflum gristbita, 108 gif ðu ne belle? hwæt ðe deofol tæleð?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 «Omai», diss’ io, «non vo’ che più favelle, 110 malvagio traditor; ch’a la tua onta 111 io porterò di te vere novelle».
query.result:
**English:**
109 "Oh, you," I said, "I don't want you to speak any more, 110 evil traitor; for to your shame 111 I will carry true news of you."
**Old English:**
109 "Eala ðu," cwæð ic, "ne wille ic ðæt ðu furðor sprecan, 110 synfulla swica; for ðinre scandlican dædum 111 ic awríte be ðe soðe tíðunge."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 «Va via», rispuose, «e ciò che tu vuoi conta; 113 ma non tacer, se tu di qua entro eschi, 114 di quel ch’ebbe or così la lingua pronta.
query.result:
**English:**
112 "Go away," he replied, "and tell what you wish; 113 but do not be silent, if you escape from here, 114 about what made your tongue so ready just now.
**Old English:**
112 "Ga wíð," he cwæð, "and ðæt ðu wille secge; 113 ac ne læt ðu, gif ðu ðanon úte cume, 114 ðæt ðe ðin tunge wæs ðus sprecende."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 El piange qui l’argento de’ Franceschi: 116 “Io vidi”, potrai dir, “quel da Duera 117 là dove i peccatori stanno freschi”.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Here the silver of the French weeps: 116 “I saw,” you will be able to say, “that one from Douai 117 where the sinners stand cool.”
**Old English:**
115 Her wepeð ðara Francena seolfor: 116 “Ic geseah,” ðu miht secgan, “ðone of Dufera 117 ðær ða synfullan cealde standað.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Se fossi domandato “Altri chi v’era?”, 119 tu hai dallato quel di Beccheria 120 di cui segò Fiorenza la gorgiera.
query.result:
**English:**
118 If you were to ask, “Who else was there?”, 119 you have at your side the one from Beccheria, 120 whose throat Florence cut.
**Old English:**
118 Gif ðu wære ðæs gefrægen “Hwa wæs ðær elles?”, 119 ðu hæfst ðær æt sidan ðone of Beccherie, 120 ðæs ða ðrote Florence ofasnede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Gianni de’ Soldanier credo che sia 122 più là con Ganellone e Tebaldello, 123 ch’aprì Faenza quando si dormia».
query.result:
**English:**
121 I believe Gianni de’ Soldanier is 122 over there with Ganelon and Tebaldello, 123 who opened Faenza while people slept.
**Old English:**
121 Ic wene ðæt Gianni de’ Soldanier sie 122 ðær ofer mid Ganellone and Tebaldello, 123 ðe ða Faenze onslāt ða ða men slēpon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Noi eravam partiti già da ello, 125 ch’io vidi due ghiacciati in una buca, 126 sì che l’un capo a l’altro era cappello;
127 e come ’l pan per fame si manduca, 128 così ’l sovran li denti a l’altro pose 129 là ’ve ’l cervel s’aggiugne con la nuca:
130 non altrimenti Tidëo si rose 131 le tempie a Menalippo per disdegno, 132 che quei faceva il teschio e l’altre cose.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 «O tu che mostri per sì bestial segno 134 odio sovra colui che tu ti mangi, 135 dimmi ’l perché», diss’ io, «per tal convegno,
136 che se tu a ragion di lui ti piangi, 137 sappiendo chi voi siete e la sua pecca, 138 nel mondo suso ancora io te ne cangi,
139 se quella con ch’io parlo non si secca».
query.result:
**English:**
133 "O you who show by such a bestial sign 134 hatred for the one you are devouring, 135 tell me the reason," I said, "by such an agreement,
136 that if you have just cause to weep for him, 137 knowing who you are and his sin, 138 in the world above I will still change your fate,
139 if that with which I speak does not dry up."
**Old English:**
133 "Eala ðu ðe ðurh ðone bestiallican tacn 134 hatst ðone ðe ðu ðær fretst, 135 sege me ðone andsware," cwæð ic, "ðurh ðone geþincðe,
136 ðæt gif ðu rihtlice ðe ðurh hine wepest, 137 ðurh ðæt ðe ðu wast hwæt ðe syndon and his syn, 138 ðæt ic ðe on ðam ufeweardan worulde ða gyt awende,
139 gif ðæt ne ðyrst ðæt ðe ic mid sprece."
